content: Why I can’t find a damn to give about WrestleMania 35WWE lacks a sense of direction and it shows in this year’s WrestleMania build and cardJ. KingBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingApr 1 from The Sportster For the first time in five years, I won’t be re-subscribing to the WWE Network to watch WrestleMania. I’ve had a waning passion for professional wrestling in general over the past year, but after this year’s Royal Rumble, I found myself bored and disinterested with WWE as a whole.The cracks in my wrestling fandom have been growing for some time. I’ve highlighted multiple concerns with the direction of WWE. My criticisms have come from a place of goodwill and sincerity. I wanted to see WWE figure out its problems and entertain me the way it did when I was a kid.Don’t get me wrong, if you go through my wrestling archives, there have been characters and feuds that I’ve enjoyed. Hell, I even thought WrestleMania 34 was going to be awful and it exceeded my expectations. Yet despite exceeding my expectations, there has been no answer to the problems I’ve called out over the past two years.My first major wrestling assessment came in an article I wrote about WWE’s struggle with building new stars. Many of the star related issues I attributed to booking, and that issue still and will exist to an extent. John Cena and Roman Reigns will always be treated as first-class individuals over anyone else in the company. It’s how the company promotes them, books them, and how each and every personality on the show talks about them.Laying the blame on booking or Cena and Reigns’ shoulders doesn’t capture the whole picture. Even in the absence of Reigns and Cena, WWE doesn’t produce an entertaining enough show for its talent to receive mainstream popularity. The highfalutin personalities and egos are almost nonexistent in today’s wrestling characters. The few guys (Samoa Joe, Kevin Owens) with lightning rod personalities are not prioritized and are often boxed in a show that lacks continuity or authentic scriptwriting.WWE’s Struggle with Building New StarsThe WWE star-power struggle is stuck somewhere between tennis and golfmedium.comWWE’s lack of success is a multi-layered problem. Before considering WWE’s star building struggle, I was already laying the groundwork for why they couldn’t build new stars.WWE lacked identity. They lacked direction. They still do. So much so in today’s iteration that I can’t be bothered to check out their YouTube clips to catch up on the weekly shows.No New Eras in the WWEThere Hasn’t Been an Era in WWE since ‘Ruthless Aggression’medium.comI’ve found every clip I watch today from a Raw or SmackDown to be baffling. The WWE is so in its own head about whether it wants to portray its show as reality TV, a sports-reality-soap opera hybrid, or as a Maury talk show, that it’s become a ghastly combination of all the above. The most asinine example of this is in the WrestleMania main event storyline where Ronda Rousey is being asked to break the fourth wall multiple times about how she’s a legit fighter against fake fighters even though they’re all fake fighting. Triple H and Drew McIntyre have also used the real names of the wrestlers they’re facing in yet another obtuse display of trying to make feuds personal.All the above factors have circulated themselves into my decision to step away from caring about wrestling. It’s not something I revere with jubilation or excitement. I’m not eager to hate wrestling. I’m disappointed. Even if wrestling will never be as popular as it was in decades past, it doesn’t have to be this bad. Wrestling storylines shouldn’t be insulting my intelligence constantly.The Road to Wrestlemania 35 has been one big slap in the face after another.In the past, I would’ve been hyped for a Seth Rollins and Brock Lesnar feud. Rollins’ matches have a high ceiling and he’s serviceable on the mic. Lesnar has Heyman to do the heavy-duty lifting on the mic while Lesnar takes care of the heavy-duty action in the ring. Lesnar is also one of the better in-ring storytellers and sellers, a quality he never gets credit for.from Rolling StoneRollins and Lesnar are slated to face each other for the Universal Championship and the build has been predictable and stale. The WWE continues to bait the gullible portion of its audience with a storyline that pins Brock Lesnar as a truant despite being notedly signed to a part-time contract. Rollins, among others, complain in their promos that they want to be fighting champions and have the championship belt on the show each week despite the fact that major championships are typically only ever defended at pay-per-view events.Despite all the pointless vernacular and fan irateness towards Lesnar, there’s been no segment or moment in the Rollins or Lesnar feud to make me excited about the match. Take that last statement, remove Lesnar and Rollins from it, and copy and paste every other match on the show in there, and you’ll have a good summary of what I’m conveying.There’s been an entertaining segment here and there. AJ Style and Randy Orton had a good back and forth on the mic which is something I never expected to write. The Miz and Shane McMahon feud has a little value but the storyline is convoluted and too far out there for me to truly buy into.Triple H and Batista has caught my eye the most as a pre-Mania build that I’m curious about. As the back and forth has progressed, the more disinterested and puzzled with the feud I’ve become. Batista blames Triple H for holding him back when Batista went on to have a hall of fame career? Why is the story making Batista seem like he lacks self-awareness? If we’re to assume he pre-meditated goading Triple H into accepting a send-off Mania match, wouldn’t his reasoning come off as more concrete and thought out?Logical fallacies are the bread and butter of today’s wrestling feuds. Movies and television have room for plot holes. When the plot holes become frequent and gaping, said program is picked apart at the seams. I can’t sit and watch WWE, comment on the lack of continuity, and read and listen to other people defend it online.Rey Mysterio is my all-time favorite wrestler. I’m a huge Samoa Joe fan. Them having a United States Championship is not turning the needle for me. It’s likely going to be a great match with great storytelling amongst a 5+ hour show where I’d be scrolling Twitter within twenty minutes looking for someone to argue Giants football with.from WWE.comThe most compelling match for discussion is the recently announced main event of Wrestlemania 35. The first ever time women will compete in a Wrestlemania main event. This match features the likes of former UFC star Ronda Rousey, facing Ric Flair’s daughter Charlotte Flair, and WWE’s budding starlet Becky Lynch.I gave Ronda and the WWE a lot of credit for how they handled her initial debut and subsequent matches. I look back at her first feud with Stephanie McMahon and would still remark it’s a dumb feud storyline wise, but the match was a success. Rousey’s mystique quickly wore off as she became a fixture of the weekly shows. Rousey’s vocal delivery wavers as she doesn’t come off as natural but rather sounds muffled when she delivers lines. On occasion, if she has to turn up the intensity, the shit talking is still in her. Rousey plays a great arrogant character, but the WWE for the longest believed she should be a face and subjected her to countless ‘kiss the fans ass’ promos that turned many fans against her.Enter in Becky Lynch, an okay wrestler who carries herself with brash confidence and has been under-utilized, and suddenly she’s gotten Daniel Bryan WrestleMania 30 booking behind her.Pause and halt the train for a moment though. Bryan’s run to 30 has marquis moments to look back on. Lynch has not been offered the same reprieve. Lynch isn’t a force of nature either despite some fans likening her to Stone Cold.Lynch is a tough-talking troll on Twitter, which works for today’s WWE audience, but on television, she doesn’t offer the same energy she uses online. Lynch also lacks name value outside of the WWE faithful. I can’t point to a Becky Lynch segment I can show my friends who haven’t watched wrestling in a decade and shock them with a clip of Becky Lynch being entertaining.Rousey has MMA credibility. Rousey has been a viral moment on many occasions. Rousey has been a draw for the UFC. What Rousey hasn’t been for WWE is a viewership draw for Raw.from The NationalBefore I forget, Charlotte Flair is in the match too simply because Vince McMahon and the company wants her to be. Name value and recognition of the Flair family name is one major root cause. Charlotte’s claim to fame was her era-defining feud with Sasha Banks. Beyond that though, Charlotte labors on the mic and her feud with Becky Lynch which should have all the potential in the world remains disjointed.As much as I feel disconnected from the storylines and the characters themselves, WWE’s hardcore audience has wedged a further gap between me and today’s brand of wrestling. That gap was solidified at Extreme Rules last year when Seth Rollins and Dolph Ziggler had what might be the last Iron Man match in history.Congratulations WWE Fans! You earned your moment. Are you happy now?This moment has been a long time comingmedium.comI’ve never quite seen anything like it. A crowd deciding that they’re more entertained with chanting at a clock than watching the wrestling show they paid money to see.Today’s WWE audience has subjugated themselves to The New Day, a team I’ve found to be disconcerting from the jump. I stopped watching their segments for the last two years and change as they pushed My Little Pony (Brony, an older male who is into My Little Pony, it’s a real thing that alleged real people are into) culture into wrestling. I already know I’m going to be in the vocal minority of wrestling fans by saying that a stable based on unicorns and rainbows being popular is terrible for WWE’s relevance in pop culture.There was a time when Kofi Kingston, Big E Langston, and Xavier Woods were all respectable wrestlers in their own right. If The New Day was treated as a heel faction, I’d have no issue with their antics. I’d still probably not watch them eat pancakes that were somewhere in the vicinity of Big E’s crotch but to each their own. I guess.Just reading those words I wrote and knowing there are scores of people who will defend it makes me painstakingly numb to wrestling and its current crop of hardcore fans. There are fans in all sports and entertainments fandoms that have either illogical or nonsensical points of view. We do live in the media generation of hot takes where being controversial is more valued than being accurate. Nonetheless, I can’t bargain with wrestling fans who can’t accept that I have a different point of view. I can have a discussion on music, movies, or sports with friends or internet dwellers and have a productive dialogue.Knowing that WWE is consistent in their commitment to please their hardcore fans and not open to experimenting with their formula to attract new or former fans is a systemic issue. There’s no immediate roadmap for professional wrestling to recapture the spectacle that made it must watch.Maybe there’ll be some dramatic shift in the alignment of the Milky Way galaxy and next year I’ll happily be back to talk about Wrestlemania 36, but I’ll worry about that when we get there. For now, Wrestlemania 35 has nothing to offer me and the millions of wrestling fans that have stopped tuning into WWE programming.
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Sign inGet started

  • Television
  • Portfolio

Why I can’t find a damn to give about WrestleMania 35

WWE lacks a sense of direction and it shows in this year’s WrestleMania build and card

J. King
Apr 1

For the first time in five years, I won’t be re-subscribing to the WWE Network to watch WrestleMania. I’ve had a waning passion for professional wrestling in general over the past year, but after this year’s Royal Rumble, I found myself bored and disinterested with WWE as a whole.

The cracks in my wrestling fandom have been growing for some time. I’ve highlighted multiple concerns with the direction of WWE. My criticisms have come from a place of goodwill and sincerity. I wanted to see WWE figure out its problems and entertain me the way it did when I was a kid.

Don’t get me wrong, if you go through my wrestling archives, there have been characters and feuds that I’ve enjoyed. Hell, I even thought WrestleMania 34 was going to be awful and it exceeded my expectations. Yet despite exceeding my expectations, there has been no answer to the problems I’ve called out over the past two years.

My first major wrestling assessment came in an article I wrote about WWE’s struggle with building new stars. Many of the star related issues I attributed to booking, and that issue still and will exist to an extent. John Cena and Roman Reigns will always be treated as first-class individuals over anyone else in the company. It’s how the company promotes them, books them, and how each and every personality on the show talks about them.

Laying the blame on booking or Cena and Reigns’ shoulders doesn’t capture the whole picture. Even in the absence of Reigns and Cena, WWE doesn’t produce an entertaining enough show for its talent to receive mainstream popularity. The highfalutin personalities and egos are almost nonexistent in today’s wrestling characters. The few guys (Samoa Joe, Kevin Owens) with lightning rod personalities are not prioritized and are often boxed in a show that lacks continuity or authentic scriptwriting.

WWE’s Struggle with Building New Stars
The WWE star-power struggle is stuck somewhere between tennis and golfmedium.com

WWE’s lack of success is a multi-layered problem. Before considering WWE’s star building struggle, I was already laying the groundwork for why they couldn’t build new stars.

WWE lacked identity. They lacked direction. They still do. So much so in today’s iteration that I can’t be bothered to check out their YouTube clips to catch up on the weekly shows.

No New Eras in the WWE
There Hasn’t Been an Era in WWE since ‘Ruthless Aggression’medium.com

I’ve found every clip I watch today from a Raw or SmackDown to be baffling. The WWE is so in its own head about whether it wants to portray its show as reality TV, a sports-reality-soap opera hybrid, or as a Maury talk show, that it’s become a ghastly combination of all the above. The most asinine example of this is in the WrestleMania main event storyline where Ronda Rousey is being asked to break the fourth wall multiple times about how she’s a legit fighter against fake fighters even though they’re all fake fighting. Triple H and Drew McIntyre have also used the real names of the wrestlers they’re facing in yet another obtuse display of trying to make feuds personal.

All the above factors have circulated themselves into my decision to step away from caring about wrestling. It’s not something I revere with jubilation or excitement. I’m not eager to hate wrestling. I’m disappointed. Even if wrestling will never be as popular as it was in decades past, it doesn’t have to be this bad. Wrestling storylines shouldn’t be insulting my intelligence constantly.

The Road to Wrestlemania 35 has been one big slap in the face after another.

In the past, I would’ve been hyped for a Seth Rollins and Brock Lesnar feud. Rollins’ matches have a high ceiling and he’s serviceable on the mic. Lesnar has Heyman to do the heavy-duty lifting on the mic while Lesnar takes care of the heavy-duty action in the ring. Lesnar is also one of the better in-ring storytellers and sellers, a quality he never gets credit for.

Rollins and Lesnar are slated to face each other for the Universal Championship and the build has been predictable and stale. The WWE continues to bait the gullible portion of its audience with a storyline that pins Brock Lesnar as a truant despite being notedly signed to a part-time contract. Rollins, among others, complain in their promos that they want to be fighting champions and have the championship belt on the show each week despite the fact that major championships are typically only ever defended at pay-per-view events.

Despite all the pointless vernacular and fan irateness towards Lesnar, there’s been no segment or moment in the Rollins or Lesnar feud to make me excited about the match. Take that last statement, remove Lesnar and Rollins from it, and copy and paste every other match on the show in there, and you’ll have a good summary of what I’m conveying.

There’s been an entertaining segment here and there. AJ Style and Randy Orton had a good back and forth on the mic which is something I never expected to write. The Miz and Shane McMahon feud has a little value but the storyline is convoluted and too far out there for me to truly buy into.

Triple H and Batista has caught my eye the most as a pre-Mania build that I’m curious about. As the back and forth has progressed, the more disinterested and puzzled with the feud I’ve become. Batista blames Triple H for holding him back when Batista went on to have a hall of fame career? Why is the story making Batista seem like he lacks self-awareness? If we’re to assume he pre-meditated goading Triple H into accepting a send-off Mania match, wouldn’t his reasoning come off as more concrete and thought out?

Logical fallacies are the bread and butter of today’s wrestling feuds. Movies and television have room for plot holes. When the plot holes become frequent and gaping, said program is picked apart at the seams. I can’t sit and watch WWE, comment on the lack of continuity, and read and listen to other people defend it online.

Rey Mysterio is my all-time favorite wrestler. I’m a huge Samoa Joe fan. Them having a United States Championship is not turning the needle for me. It’s likely going to be a great match with great storytelling amongst a 5+ hour show where I’d be scrolling Twitter within twenty minutes looking for someone to argue Giants football with.

The most compelling match for discussion is the recently announced main event of Wrestlemania 35. The first ever time women will compete in a Wrestlemania main event. This match features the likes of former UFC star Ronda Rousey, facing Ric Flair’s daughter Charlotte Flair, and WWE’s budding starlet Becky Lynch.

I gave Ronda and the WWE a lot of credit for how they handled her initial debut and subsequent matches. I look back at her first feud with Stephanie McMahon and would still remark it’s a dumb feud storyline wise, but the match was a success. Rousey’s mystique quickly wore off as she became a fixture of the weekly shows. Rousey’s vocal delivery wavers as she doesn’t come off as natural but rather sounds muffled when she delivers lines. On occasion, if she has to turn up the intensity, the shit talking is still in her. Rousey plays a great arrogant character, but the WWE for the longest believed she should be a face and subjected her to countless ‘kiss the fans ass’ promos that turned many fans against her.

Enter in Becky Lynch, an okay wrestler who carries herself with brash confidence and has been under-utilized, and suddenly she’s gotten Daniel Bryan WrestleMania 30 booking behind her.

Pause and halt the train for a moment though. Bryan’s run to 30 has marquis moments to look back on. Lynch has not been offered the same reprieve. Lynch isn’t a force of nature either despite some fans likening her to Stone Cold.

Lynch is a tough-talking troll on Twitter, which works for today’s WWE audience, but on television, she doesn’t offer the same energy she uses online. Lynch also lacks name value outside of the WWE faithful. I can’t point to a Becky Lynch segment I can show my friends who haven’t watched wrestling in a decade and shock them with a clip of Becky Lynch being entertaining.

Rousey has MMA credibility. Rousey has been a viral moment on many occasions. Rousey has been a draw for the UFC. What Rousey hasn’t been for WWE is a viewership draw for Raw.

Before I forget, Charlotte Flair is in the match too simply because Vince McMahon and the company wants her to be. Name value and recognition of the Flair family name is one major root cause. Charlotte’s claim to fame was her era-defining feud with Sasha Banks. Beyond that though, Charlotte labors on the mic and her feud with Becky Lynch which should have all the potential in the world remains disjointed.

As much as I feel disconnected from the storylines and the characters themselves, WWE’s hardcore audience has wedged a further gap between me and today’s brand of wrestling. That gap was solidified at Extreme Rules last year when Seth Rollins and Dolph Ziggler had what might be the last Iron Man match in history.

Congratulations WWE Fans! You earned your moment. Are you happy now?
This moment has been a long time comingmedium.com

I’ve never quite seen anything like it. A crowd deciding that they’re more entertained with chanting at a clock than watching the wrestling show they paid money to see.

Today’s WWE audience has subjugated themselves to The New Day, a team I’ve found to be disconcerting from the jump. I stopped watching their segments for the last two years and change as they pushed My Little Pony (Brony, an older male who is into My Little Pony, it’s a real thing that alleged real people are into) culture into wrestling. I already know I’m going to be in the vocal minority of wrestling fans by saying that a stable based on unicorns and rainbows being popular is terrible for WWE’s relevance in pop culture.

There was a time when Kofi Kingston, Big E Langston, and Xavier Woods were all respectable wrestlers in their own right. If The New Day was treated as a heel faction, I’d have no issue with their antics. I’d still probably not watch them eat pancakes that were somewhere in the vicinity of Big E’s crotch but to each their own. I guess.

Just reading those words I wrote and knowing there are scores of people who will defend it makes me painstakingly numb to wrestling and its current crop of hardcore fans. There are fans in all sports and entertainments fandoms that have either illogical or nonsensical points of view. We do live in the media generation of hot takes where being controversial is more valued than being accurate. Nonetheless, I can’t bargain with wrestling fans who can’t accept that I have a different point of view. I can have a discussion on music, movies, or sports with friends or internet dwellers and have a productive dialogue.

Knowing that WWE is consistent in their commitment to please their hardcore fans and not open to experimenting with their formula to attract new or former fans is a systemic issue. There’s no immediate roadmap for professional wrestling to recapture the spectacle that made it must watch.

Maybe there’ll be some dramatic shift in the alignment of the Milky Way galaxy and next year I’ll happily be back to talk about Wrestlemania 36, but I’ll worry about that when we get there. For now, Wrestlemania 35 has nothing to offer me and the millions of wrestling fans that have stopped tuning into WWE programming.

  • WWE
  • Wrestling
  • Wrestlemania
  • Vince McMahon
  • Storytelling

  • J. King

    Varied half-sensible ramblings and rants on Sports, Wrestling, Entertainment, Film, Gaming, Music

  • Casual Rambling

    Casually discussing or ranting about film, TV, sports, gaming, wrestling, or music
title: Why I can’t find a damn to give about WrestleMania 35
title_html: Why I can’t find a damn to give about WrestleMania 35
content_html:
Why I can’t find a damn to give about WrestleMania 35

WWE lacks a sense of direction and it shows in this year’s WrestleMania build and card

J. King
Apr 1

For the first time in five years, I won’t be re-subscribing to the WWE Network to watch WrestleMania. I’ve had a waning passion for professional wrestling in general over the past year, but after this year’s Royal Rumble, I found myself bored and disinterested with WWE as a whole.

The cracks in my wrestling fandom have been growing for some time. I’ve highlighted multiple concerns with the direction of WWE. My criticisms have come from a place of goodwill and sincerity. I wanted to see WWE figure out its problems and entertain me the way it did when I was a kid.

Don’t get me wrong, if you go through my wrestling archives, there have been characters and feuds that I’ve enjoyed. Hell, I even thought WrestleMania 34 was going to be awful and it exceeded my expectations. Yet despite exceeding my expectations, there has been no answer to the problems I’ve called out over the past two years.

My first major wrestling assessment came in an article I wrote about WWE’s struggle with building new stars. Many of the star related issues I attributed to booking, and that issue still and will exist to an extent. John Cena and Roman Reigns will always be treated as first-class individuals over anyone else in the company. It’s how the company promotes them, books them, and how each and every personality on the show talks about them.

Laying the blame on booking or Cena and Reigns’ shoulders doesn’t capture the whole picture. Even in the absence of Reigns and Cena, WWE doesn’t produce an entertaining enough show for its talent to receive mainstream popularity. The highfalutin personalities and egos are almost nonexistent in today’s wrestling characters. The few guys (Samoa Joe, Kevin Owens) with lightning rod personalities are not prioritized and are often boxed in a show that lacks continuity or authentic scriptwriting.

WWE’s Struggle with Building New Stars
The WWE star-power struggle is stuck somewhere between tennis and golfmedium.com

WWE’s lack of success is a multi-layered problem. Before considering WWE’s star building struggle, I was already laying the groundwork for why they couldn’t build new stars.

WWE lacked identity. They lacked direction. They still do. So much so in today’s iteration that I can’t be bothered to check out their YouTube clips to catch up on the weekly shows.

No New Eras in the WWE
There Hasn’t Been an Era in WWE since ‘Ruthless Aggression’medium.com

I’ve found every clip I watch today from a Raw or SmackDown to be baffling. The WWE is so in its own head about whether it wants to portray its show as reality TV, a sports-reality-soap opera hybrid, or as a Maury talk show, that it’s become a ghastly combination of all the above. The most asinine example of this is in the WrestleMania main event storyline where Ronda Rousey is being asked to break the fourth wall multiple times about how she’s a legit fighter against fake fighters even though they’re all fake fighting. Triple H and Drew McIntyre have also used the real names of the wrestlers they’re facing in yet another obtuse display of trying to make feuds personal.

All the above factors have circulated themselves into my decision to step away from caring about wrestling. It’s not something I revere with jubilation or excitement. I’m not eager to hate wrestling. I’m disappointed. Even if wrestling will never be as popular as it was in decades past, it doesn’t have to be this bad. Wrestling storylines shouldn’t be insulting my intelligence constantly.

The Road to Wrestlemania 35 has been one big slap in the face after another.

In the past, I would’ve been hyped for a Seth Rollins and Brock Lesnar feud. Rollins’ matches have a high ceiling and he’s serviceable on the mic. Lesnar has Heyman to do the heavy-duty lifting on the mic while Lesnar takes care of the heavy-duty action in the ring. Lesnar is also one of the better in-ring storytellers and sellers, a quality he never gets credit for.

Rollins and Lesnar are slated to face each other for the Universal Championship and the build has been predictable and stale. The WWE continues to bait the gullible portion of its audience with a storyline that pins Brock Lesnar as a truant despite being notedly signed to a part-time contract. Rollins, among others, complain in their promos that they want to be fighting champions and have the championship belt on the show each week despite the fact that major championships are typically only ever defended at pay-per-view events.

Despite all the pointless vernacular and fan irateness towards Lesnar, there’s been no segment or moment in the Rollins or Lesnar feud to make me excited about the match. Take that last statement, remove Lesnar and Rollins from it, and copy and paste every other match on the show in there, and you’ll have a good summary of what I’m conveying.

There’s been an entertaining segment here and there. AJ Style and Randy Orton had a good back and forth on the mic which is something I never expected to write. The Miz and Shane McMahon feud has a little value but the storyline is convoluted and too far out there for me to truly buy into.

Triple H and Batista has caught my eye the most as a pre-Mania build that I’m curious about. As the back and forth has progressed, the more disinterested and puzzled with the feud I’ve become. Batista blames Triple H for holding him back when Batista went on to have a hall of fame career? Why is the story making Batista seem like he lacks self-awareness? If we’re to assume he pre-meditated goading Triple H into accepting a send-off Mania match, wouldn’t his reasoning come off as more concrete and thought out?

Logical fallacies are the bread and butter of today’s wrestling feuds. Movies and television have room for plot holes. When the plot holes become frequent and gaping, said program is picked apart at the seams. I can’t sit and watch WWE, comment on the lack of continuity, and read and listen to other people defend it online.

Rey Mysterio is my all-time favorite wrestler. I’m a huge Samoa Joe fan. Them having a United States Championship is not turning the needle for me. It’s likely going to be a great match with great storytelling amongst a 5+ hour show where I’d be scrolling Twitter within twenty minutes looking for someone to argue Giants football with.

The most compelling match for discussion is the recently announced main event of Wrestlemania 35. The first ever time women will compete in a Wrestlemania main event. This match features the likes of former UFC star Ronda Rousey, facing Ric Flair’s daughter Charlotte Flair, and WWE’s budding starlet Becky Lynch.

I gave Ronda and the WWE a lot of credit for how they handled her initial debut and subsequent matches. I look back at her first feud with Stephanie McMahon and would still remark it’s a dumb feud storyline wise, but the match was a success. Rousey’s mystique quickly wore off as she became a fixture of the weekly shows. Rousey’s vocal delivery wavers as she doesn’t come off as natural but rather sounds muffled when she delivers lines. On occasion, if she has to turn up the intensity, the shit talking is still in her. Rousey plays a great arrogant character, but the WWE for the longest believed she should be a face and subjected her to countless ‘kiss the fans ass’ promos that turned many fans against her.

Enter in Becky Lynch, an okay wrestler who carries herself with brash confidence and has been under-utilized, and suddenly she’s gotten Daniel Bryan WrestleMania 30 booking behind her.

Pause and halt the train for a moment though. Bryan’s run to 30 has marquis moments to look back on. Lynch has not been offered the same reprieve. Lynch isn’t a force of nature either despite some fans likening her to Stone Cold.

Lynch is a tough-talking troll on Twitter, which works for today’s WWE audience, but on television, she doesn’t offer the same energy she uses online. Lynch also lacks name value outside of the WWE faithful. I can’t point to a Becky Lynch segment I can show my friends who haven’t watched wrestling in a decade and shock them with a clip of Becky Lynch being entertaining.

Rousey has MMA credibility. Rousey has been a viral moment on many occasions. Rousey has been a draw for the UFC. What Rousey hasn’t been for WWE is a viewership draw for Raw.

Before I forget, Charlotte Flair is in the match too simply because Vince McMahon and the company wants her to be. Name value and recognition of the Flair family name is one major root cause. Charlotte’s claim to fame was her era-defining feud with Sasha Banks. Beyond that though, Charlotte labors on the mic and her feud with Becky Lynch which should have all the potential in the world remains disjointed.

As much as I feel disconnected from the storylines and the characters themselves, WWE’s hardcore audience has wedged a further gap between me and today’s brand of wrestling. That gap was solidified at Extreme Rules last year when Seth Rollins and Dolph Ziggler had what might be the last Iron Man match in history.

Congratulations WWE Fans! You earned your moment. Are you happy now?
This moment has been a long time comingmedium.com

I’ve never quite seen anything like it. A crowd deciding that they’re more entertained with chanting at a clock than watching the wrestling show they paid money to see.

Today’s WWE audience has subjugated themselves to The New Day, a team I’ve found to be disconcerting from the jump. I stopped watching their segments for the last two years and change as they pushed My Little Pony (Brony, an older male who is into My Little Pony, it’s a real thing that alleged real people are into) culture into wrestling. I already know I’m going to be in the vocal minority of wrestling fans by saying that a stable based on unicorns and rainbows being popular is terrible for WWE’s relevance in pop culture.

There was a time when Kofi Kingston, Big E Langston, and Xavier Woods were all respectable wrestlers in their own right. If The New Day was treated as a heel faction, I’d have no issue with their antics. I’d still probably not watch them eat pancakes that were somewhere in the vicinity of Big E’s crotch but to each their own. I guess.

Just reading those words I wrote and knowing there are scores of people who will defend it makes me painstakingly numb to wrestling and its current crop of hardcore fans. There are fans in all sports and entertainments fandoms that have either illogical or nonsensical points of view. We do live in the media generation of hot takes where being controversial is more valued than being accurate. Nonetheless, I can’t bargain with wrestling fans who can’t accept that I have a different point of view. I can have a discussion on music, movies, or sports with friends or internet dwellers and have a productive dialogue.

Knowing that WWE is consistent in their commitment to please their hardcore fans and not open to experimenting with their formula to attract new or former fans is a systemic issue. There’s no immediate roadmap for professional wrestling to recapture the spectacle that made it must watch.

Maybe there’ll be some dramatic shift in the alignment of the Milky Way galaxy and next year I’ll happily be back to talk about Wrestlemania 36, but I’ll worry about that when we get there. For now, Wrestlemania 35 has nothing to offer me and the millions of wrestling fans that have stopped tuning into WWE programming.
